reviewText: The Laurel and Hardy bits are slightly amusing - the rest of the film is paper thin. Try to catch it on Turner Classic Movies. It's not really much of a film.

reviewText: ANOTHER GREAT FILM FROM THE WARNER ARCHIVE COLLECTION, SPECIALLY FOR THOSE LAUREL AND HARDY FANS AS THIS FEATURE CONTAINS A GREAT SEQUENCE OF THIS DUO COMEDIANS.I'M A MEMBER OF THE WARNER ARCHIVE...AND WAITING FOR MORE CLASSICS TO BE RELEASED LIKE "WHOOPEE" AND MANY OTHERS BUT FOUND THIS DVD AT LESS EXPENSIDE PRICE ON AMAZON. A MUST HAVE FOR GREAT FILM COLLECTORS

reviewText: Pick a Star(released May/37)was a Hal Roach vehicle for his then stable of stars,among others,Rosina Lawrence,Patsy Kelly,Jack Haley,Mischa Auer and Lyda Roberti.Laurel and Hardy,though the heaviest of the heavyweights on screen,receive no opening or closing credits.Roach wanted something to really boost this film and they were "it".The film has a rather weak premise.Rosina Lawrence is a country girl who wins a small town beauty pageant.The contest gets bilked out of the prize money and her boyfriend Haley goes to Hollywood to work as a waiter in a restaurant to earn the money to bring Lawrence there.What should happen,but a plane flying to Hollywood is forced to land near Lawrence's home town and one of the passengers gives up his two tickets for her and her sister(Kelly).On the plane with them is a Hollywood star,Auer,who shows Lawrence the town once they arrive.Haley's gig at the restaurant comes to a crashing halt when Lawrence and her sister show up there thinking he is part of the entertainment,but isn't.Auer takes advantage and tries to seduce Lawrence at his home.Trouble is it was Haley who drove them there from the studio,at which he now works.The inevitable confrontation occurs between Haley and Auer,with the result that Lawrence gets a screen test.Lawrence,through nerves,is about to blow it until Haley comes in and calms her enough to save the day.Of course the highlight of this entire film is Laurel and Hardy.They are seen when Lawrence and Kelly first get a tour of the studio shortly after arriving in Hollywood.Then later when Lawrence is about to get her screen test.James Finlayson is the set upon director of the Boys,with his famous squint plainly in evidence.The first time we see them,the boys are in a scene where they are feared banditos.They belly up to the bar where their long arch nemesis from a score of their films is there,Walter Long.They exchange bottle hits over the head until they run out.Fin yells cut and Kelly goes over to talk to The Boys.In a very relaxed verbal exchange Stan and Oliver talk about the breakaway bottles they use.Oliver calls for a bottle from the prop boy,but it's real.Oliver says go ahead hit me,it's ok.She does and he's wobbling on his feet.Stan is next and they both keel over out of sight! Absolutely priceless stuff.The next encounter finds the Boys relaxing on a small settee.First Stan is playing on a large harmonica that you blow into.Its tone eventually turns into a tuba sound at which point Ollie tells him to quit.Next Stan and Ollie trade shots at playing ever smaller mouth organs.The tiny one Ollie finally uses he swallows and Stan ends up playing his stomach.Again priceless to watch and worth the price of the movie by itself.Lawrence is just a bit too weak to carry the picture by herself.Haley is a bit of a help and Auer really plays his part a bit too over the top for my liking.Besides the Boys,Kelly is the next best thing in it,as she mugs,smart talks and barks her way through calamity after calamity.Auer:"Do you mind if I smoke?",Kelly:"I don't care if you burn".Have always loved that one.The film is in its original a/r and extras include the trailer.This film comes in at about 70 minutes,but as we know it is supposed to come in at around 76 minutes.Why MGM/Warners would reissue this in a truncated form I do not know.This film,like all of these on-demand releases through Warners,needs a cleaning up and remastering.All in all,if you,like me,wanted Pick a Star to complete your Laurel and Hardy collection,it is for you.It is a cut 70 minute version of the picture though,and needs a good remastering.Other than the Boys and Kelly,there is nothing really to recommend this picture to you for.2 1/2 stars.
summary: Pick a Star-the truncated version 2 1/2 stars-

reviewText: Director Edward Sedgwick, an old hand at visual comedy, successfully leads this Hal Roach road show which tenders a fast-moving and adroit scenario and excellent casting, employing a large number of Roach's reliable performers. Although the film was originally plotted as a vehicle for Patsy Kelly, sunny Jack Haley stars as Joe Jenkins, a young Kansan who sells his auto repair business and journeys to Hollywood, where he attempts to wangle a screen role for the girl he loves, star-struck Cecilia (Rosina Lawrence). Sedgwick, who prefers using the entire M-G-M studio as his set, does so here as Cecilia, always ready for an audition, is treated by a would-be paramour, cinema star Rinaldo Lopez (Mischa Auer), to behind-the-scenes action of, naturally, a musical comedy, featuring Broadway headliner Lyda Roberti. Laurel and Hardy provide several enjoyable interludes, including their well-known skit involving a tiny harmonica, and we watch fine turns by such as Joyce Compton, Russell Hicks and Walter Long. On balance, one must hand the bays to Mischa Auer, who clearly steals the picture as an emotional movie star, a role which he largely creates, and to the director for his clever closing homage to Busby Berkeley's filmic spectacles.
summary: Musical comedy feast, with Laurel and Hardy on the side.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy add some box-office insurance to the musical comedy "Pick a Star" (1937). Producer Hal Roach creates an agreeable showcase for the talents of Rosina Lawrence, Patsy Kelly, Jack Haley, Mischa Auer and Lyda Roberti. No hidden classic but a pleasant diversion, with guest stars Stan and Ollie contributing two memorable sequences. Edward Sedgwick later directed The Boys in MGM's lackluster "Air Raid Wardens" (1943).
summary: Pleasant Musical-Comedy With Two L&H Scenes

reviewText: Well, I bought this movie to add it to my Laurel & Hardy collection...however this is in no way a Laurel & Hardy film.  They make a cameo in this movie really.  The movie overall wasn't bad.  It was actually a pretty decent film about a girl dying to make it in Hollywood.  I wouldn't recommend this movie to a Laurel & Hardy fan but if you like old movie classics you will probably enjoy this one.
summary: Pick a star aka movie struck
